Issues.Title: title/subtitle rendered in single line in Hero container
Issues.Body:
Hi, 

I noticed that the both "hero is-halfheight" and "hero is-fullheight" will make title/subtitle inside "hero-body" rendered in a single line instead of two. We can workaround this by wrap them in an extra `<div>` tag. Not sure if this is the intended design or a bug. But if it is intended design, it probably should at least be noted in the documentation and state the reason why we need this?

See https://bulma.io/documentation/layout/hero/#halfheight-hero and https://bulma.io/documentation/layout/hero/#fullheight-hero
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "title/subtitle rendered in single line in Hero container" (#3442)

Issues.Title: Multiple css files
Issues.Body: Bulma is currently only [one CSS file](https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/blob/master/css/bulma.css). It would be way more useful if there were multiple CSS files, meaning there is one file for each component,  element, or concept just like the [SASS files](https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/tree/master/sass). If this was also a thing for CSS we could just import **only** the CDN files we need instead of one big CSS file. When I use my Bulma CSS on [Google Lighthouse](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse), I am told that there is lots of unused CSS. This makes the website way slower. The best solution would be those multiple CSS files. I know this is already a thing for SASS, but it is complicated to set up, especially for static site generators. I would strongly appreciate it if someone made this change possible. Please let me know what you think of this suggestion, and how likely it is to be implemented. I hope you understand my problem and how to fix it.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Multiple css files" (#3429)

Issues.Title: Replace disabled attr on pagination anchor elements with is-disabled …
Issues.Body:
…class (#3296)

<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->
<!-- DO NOT REBUILD THE CSS OUTPUT IN YOUR PR -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is a **bugfix**.
#3296

### Proposed solution

Since the `disabled` boolean attribute is not valid on an anchor element, we extend the &[disabled] selector to include &.is-disabled. The docs are updated, with the **invalid HTML replaced**. This is not a breaking change, because the original selector is still in place.

### Tradeoffs

The only drawback I can think of is that the `disabled` is still used in other places in the framework (since it is valid on `button` tags), there is a slightly higher cognitive load on devs. However, ability to write compliant HTML would seem to outweight this.

Possibly, maintainers could consider whether `.is-disabled` can be used as an alternative throughout the entire framework as a utility class. 

### Testing Done

I'm currently building a gatsby site with Bulma and I tested that I can use this class via building the project and symlinking Bulma.

    justify-content: center
    &:not(.has-addons)
      .button:not(.is-fullwidth)
        margin-left: 0.25rem
        margin-right: 0.25rem
  &.is-right
    justify-content: flex-end
    &:not(.has-addons)
      .button:not(.is-fullwidth)
        margin-left: 0.25rem
        margin-right: 0.25rem
```


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Follow the documented procedure to custom the library to override variables with 'pixel' unit instead of 'rem' units.
2. Open generated .css file to find some of the classes still uses 'rem' units.

### Expected behavior

All units overrideable

### Actual behavior

Button margins are still in rem units.

_Side note: Why is the github issue template using HTML comments when we're writing in Markdown??_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Button margins cannot be overridden because they're hardcoded to 'rem' units" (#3422)

Issues.Title: Problem with `Dropdown` component in RTL
Issues.Body:
This is about **Bulma**. ### Overview of the problem I'm using Bulma **version** [0.9.3] My **browser** is: Chrome 91.0.4472.114 (Official Build) (64-bit) ### Description The **Dropdown** component is **RTL**(Right to left) in a RTL compiled sass(`$rtl: true;`) and having `dir="rtl"` in the body tag which it should't be because it will lose the meaning of `.is-right` class. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Copy and pasted the **Dropdown** component Here's the codes I used: ```HTML

The dropdown is left-aligned by default.

``` 2. Here's a screenshot of results ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/53313989/134768426-575d31da-b70c-401c-b938-4aaf127df056.png) ### Expected behavior Here's a screenshot of expected behaviour: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/53313989/134768563-b684afb9-817e-4778-8313-d891918f5144.png) The **Dropdown** should not be **RTL** in a **RTL** compiled sass/css because what's the point of being left aligned by default when it's not in a RTL environment My solution is to make it **Left aligned** in RTL by default and if the user wanted to make it **Right aligned**, he has to use the `.is-right` class. Thank you.

Issues.Title: Improve catagories menu scrolling
Issues.Body:
Scrolling through the categories menu, especially on long documentation pages, is very difficult. Allowing overflowing content to scroll will allow users to browser the menu without the need to scroll down to the bottom of the page (or top) to see all items.

This is a **improvement**.

### Proposed solution

- Set the categories menu overflow to scrolling.
- Set the height of the categories menu to 100vh to ensure it scrolls correctly (and so everything can be seen).

### Tradeoffs

There shouldn't be many major tradeoffs. Everything seems to be working fine on desktop and mobile devices.

### Testing Done

Tested on desktop browser (Firefox/Chrome) and mobile browser (Safari).

### Changelog updated?

No.

<!-- Thanks! -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Improve catagories menu scrolling" (#3418)
